page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 229: Line 229:
[[File:Broadcast of the revolution.jpg|thumb|The so-called ''Etha'et al-thawra'' (broadcast of the revolution), set upon an elevated stage and used by the demonstrators in Tahrir Square to address the crowds. In the background is the [[American University in Cairo]].]]
[[File:Broadcast of the revolution.jpg|thumb|The so-called ''Etha'et al-thawra'' (broadcast of the revolution), set upon an elevated stage and used by the demonstrators in Tahrir Square to address the crowds. In the background is the [[American University in Cairo]].]]
â
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/us-egypt-protests-idUSTRE7141S820110205 |title=Egypt army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-04-08}}. Reuters. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> and asked them to return home. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organised and present than on any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" /> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners including an English protester on the 5th and a Swede on the 6th<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Swedish_protester_in_Tahrir.jpg |title=File:Swedish protester in Tahrir.jpg - Wikimedia Commons |publisher=Commons.wikimedia.org |date=2011-02-06 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing out flowers in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English. Five hundred protesters arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez. There were reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" />
+
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/us-egypt-protests-idUSTRE7141S820110205 |title=Egypt army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-04-08}}. Reuters. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> and asked them to return home. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organized and present than on any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" /> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners including an English protester on the 5th and a Swede on the 6th<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Swedish_protester_in_Tahrir.jpg |title=File:Swedish protester in Tahrir.jpg - Wikimedia Commons |publisher=Commons.wikimedia.org |date=2011-02-06 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing out flowers in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English. Five hundred protesters arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez. There were reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" />
State television announced the appointment of [[Hossam Badrawi]] ''(seen as a member of the liberal wing of the party)''<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" /> as Head of the Shura Council after [[Safwat El-Sherif]]'s resignation from his position within the party. Mubarak's son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] also resigned as Assistant Secretary and Secretary of the Policy Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/05/136363.html |title=Ø¥ÙØµØ§Ø¡ Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù.. ÙØªØ¹ÙÙÙ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø§ÙÙ Ø£ÙÙÙØ§ |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Minister of State for Legal Affairs Mufid Shehab and Presidential Chief-of-Staff [[Zakaria Azmy]] were dismissed from the party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/310041 |title=NDP overhaul a meager concession, says opposition | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Initial reports indicated that Mubarak had resigned as head of the ruling NDP party,<ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dowling |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/mubarak-focuses-on-economic-issues-as-protests-continue-2011-02/ |title=Protests continue in Egypt as NDP leadership resigns Â· TheJournal |publisher=Thejournal.ie |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> however this was later denied by state television and the Information Minister.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hossam Badrawi replaces NDP's Secretary general Safwat El Sherif and Gamal Mubarak|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/5039.aspx|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Ahram Online|date=5 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Information Minister denies Mubarak's resignation from ruling party|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311088|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=6 February 2011}}</ref> Former Interior Minister Habib el-Adli and three of his leadership were put under house arrest. There had been reports about the arrest of other security leaders who were being held in a military prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/308543|title=Egyptâs attorney-general bans former ministers and officials from travel|publisherAlmasry Alyoum|date= |accessdate=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, the opposition leaders continued to seek ways to remove Mubarak from power. They called on the protesters to continue at Tahrir Square every Tuesday and Friday until Mubarak "resigns and makes true the demands of the people."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" />
State television announced the appointment of [[Hossam Badrawi]] ''(seen as a member of the liberal wing of the party)''<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" /> as Head of the Shura Council after [[Safwat El-Sherif]]'s resignation from his position within the party. Mubarak's son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] also resigned as Assistant Secretary and Secretary of the Policy Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/05/136363.html |title=Ø¥ÙØµØ§Ø¡ Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù.. ÙØªØ¹ÙÙÙ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø§ÙÙ Ø£ÙÙÙØ§ |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Minister of State for Legal Affairs Mufid Shehab and Presidential Chief-of-Staff [[Zakaria Azmy]] were dismissed from the party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/310041 |title=NDP overhaul a meager concession, says opposition | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Initial reports indicated that Mubarak had resigned as head of the ruling NDP party,<ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dowling |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/mubarak-focuses-on-economic-issues-as-protests-continue-2011-02/ |title=Protests continue in Egypt as NDP leadership resigns Â· TheJournal |publisher=Thejournal.ie |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> however this was later denied by state television and the Information Minister.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hossam Badrawi replaces NDP's Secretary general Safwat El Sherif and Gamal Mubarak|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/5039.aspx|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Ahram Online|date=5 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Information Minister denies Mubarak's resignation from ruling party|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311088|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=6 February 2011}}</ref> Former Interior Minister Habib el-Adli and three of his leadership were put under house arrest. There had been reports about the arrest of other security leaders who were being held in a military prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/308543|title=Egyptâs attorney-general bans former ministers and officials from travel|publisherAlmasry Alyoum|date= |accessdate=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, the opposition leaders continued to seek ways to remove Mubarak from power. They called on the protesters to continue at Tahrir Square every Tuesday and Friday until Mubarak "resigns and makes true the demands of the people."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" />
